[VERMILLION (MANG or SINDOOR) WEARING...... IS ONE OF THE SIXTEEN MAKEUP OF INDIAN WOMEN SINCE ANCIENT TIME]:

>>VERMILLION (MANG or SINDOOR) WEARING: …A red cosmetic powder…..Sindoor is traditionally applied at the beginning or completely along the parting-line of a woman’s hair (also called maang) or as a dot on the forehead. Sindoor is the mark of a married woman in Hinduism. Single women wear the dot in different colors ("bindi" in Hindi) but do not apply sindoor in their maang. Hindu widows do not wear sindoor, signifying that their husband is no longer alive. The Indian Tridune says that there is a scientific reason behing applying sindoor along the parting of the hair for “…there lays the most important spot, the spiritual center called Brahmarandhra, an aperture in the crown of the head.”

>> SIXTEEN MAKE UP OF INDIAN WOMEN:
The 16 makeup of Indian women has its roots in ancient times…. and when embraced…… it dictates the sixteen adornments that complete a Hindu women….Say sixteen adornments as it is the most literal translation of the word Solah (sixteen) Shringar (adornments).

>>WHY SIXTEEN? According to the Hindu mythology, there is a coherent link between a woman’s menstrual cycle and the lunar cycle. While this theory has been ousted by scientists in the 20th century, its influence on Indian culture still remains. The tradition of using sixteen adornments in the Solah Shringar was crafted to nullify the effect of the sixteen phases of the moon, which in turn was believed to be connected to a women’s menstrual cycle.

>>>>SIXTEEN MAKE UP OF INDIAN WOMEN:
